Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating Giant Panda Population Dynamics through Extraction of Volatile Compounds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Giant panda populations have become isolated and fragmented throughout their natural habitat in China, making it difficult to locate potential mates. Giant pandas rely on chemical cues in order to communicate identity, kinship, and reproductive status to other individuals. However, limited information exists on the ability of giant pandas to communicate across a fragmented landscape. Therefore, this study will collect compounds from the air throughout the natural environment and analyze these components to assess individual movement, habitat use, and communication across fragmented habitats. This research will be conducted in the Sichuan province of China under the mentorship of Dr. Zhang Zejun at China West Normal University. Dr. Zhang Zejun not only offers expert knowledge regarding giant panda reproduction and habitat use, but also provides access to field locations, cameras, and analytical equipment required to implement this study. This research will develop a novel tool that will potentially connect isolated populations and contribute to conservation efforts of this iconic species.

The elusive giant panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca) utilizes volatile chemical cues to determine identity, gender, and sexual receptivity of conspecifics across fragmented habitats. With isolated populations still at risk for extinction, this study aims to identify unique volatile chemical profiles detectable in air that vary with distribution and habitat in free-ranging giant pandas. Field air analysis and solid phase micro-extraction (SPME) will be used to collect volatile compounds from free-ranging giant pandas occupying the Sichuan province of China. In collaboration with Dr. Zhang Zejun at China West Normal University, volatile compounds will be captured from the environment by securing SPME fibers along known giant panda routes and scent-marking stations. Extracted volatile compounds will be analyzed with gas chromatography mass spectrometry in order to determine differences in the volatile air profile relative to identity, gender, and site location. This research will provide valuable knowledge of giant panda population dynamics and communication across a fragmented landscape.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. Graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Abbey Wilson completed research for her dissertation "Chemical signaling by giant pandas to communicate sexual receptivity" with support from the National Science Foundation East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes in China for U.S. Graduate Students in Science and Engineering fellowship. During her funding period, she spent 2 months in China conducting both field and laboratory research. As a chemical ecologist, Abbey was interested in giant panda chemical communication and specifically, developing new techniques to collect pheromones produced by giant pandas in the wild. Abbey and her research team at Mississippi State University had developed a novel sampling technique with captive giant pandas to collect pheromones from the environment using a solid phase microextraction (SPME) fiber.  

Abbey conducted her field research in the Wolong Nature Reserve (Sichuan, China) in collaboration with China West Normal University (Nanchong, Sichuan, China). Giant pandas are known to use chemical cues in gland secretions and urine to determine specific traits about other individuals, such as identity and gender. Therefore, the goal was to collect these chemical cues using SPME fibers. With the help of local field guides and other graduate students, Abbey placed trail cameras and SPME fibers at different trees where giant pandas are thought to scent mark.

The SPME fibers were collected and returned to China West Normal University for laboratory analysis. Compounds adsorbed onto the SPME fibers were analyzed with gas chromatography/mass spectrometry. Trail cameras showed visits from a masked palm civet, Asian badger, and giant panda. The giant panda actively performed the scent marking beahvior at the sampling location beneath the secured SPME fibers. Abbey was able to identify 7 compounds that were elevated in samples collected during the giant panda visit. Furthermore, 3 of these compounds were unique to the giant panda visit. By identifying compounds that giant pandas use to communicate, wildlife managers can better understand the population dynamics and communication methods of this species.

Abbey graduated and published her dissertation in December 2017. This dissertation and the manuscripts to follow provide an imporant contribution to Science and Technology by better understanding how a unqiue and solitary species, such as the giant panda, communicates across fragmented landscapes. This research has the potential to transform how ecologists use analytical chemistry for the management of wild animal populations by providing alternative methods for population census, tracking of movements, and individual relocation.
